sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations with multiple solutions
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations for x, y, and z:

x + y + 2z = 10
2x - y + z = 3
x - 3y + 4z = 9

What are the values of x, y, and z that satisfy all three equations?
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations, we can use the method of substitution or elimination. In this case, we will use the elimination method.

First, we will eliminate y from the first two equations. To do this, we will multiply the first equation by 1 and the second equation by 1, so that when we add the two equations, the y terms will cancel out.

1*(x + y + 2z) = 1*(10)
1*(2x - y + z) = 1*(3)

This gives us:

x + y + 2z = 10
2x - y + z = 3

Now, add the two equations:

(x + y + 2z) + (2x - y + z) = 10 + 3
3x + 3z = 13

Now, we will eliminate y from the second and third equations. To do this, we will multiply the second equation by 3 and the third equation by 1, so that when we subtract the two equations, the y terms will cancel out.

3*(2x - y + z) = 3*(3)
1*(x - 3y + 4z) = 1*(9)

This gives us:

6x - 3y + 3z = 9
x - 3y + 4z = 9

Now, subtract the second equation from the first:

(6x - 3y + 3z) - (x - 3y + 4z) = 9 - 9
5x - z = 0

Now we have two equations with two variables:

3x + 3z = 13
5x - z = 0

We can solve for z in the second equation:

z = 5x

Now substitute this expression for z back into the first equation:

3x + 3(5x) = 13
3x + 15x = 13
18x = 13

Now solve for x:

x = 13/18

Now substitute the value of x back into the expression for z:

z = 5(13/18)
z = 65/18

Now we will substitute the values of x and z back into one of the original equations to find the value of y. We will use the first equation:

(13/18) + y + 2(65/18) = 10

Multiply both sides by 18 to eliminate the fractions:

13 + 18y + 130 = 180
18y = 37
y = 37/18

So the solution to the system of linear equations is:

x = 13/18
y = 37/18
z = 65/18
